data.text:
By Arthur James Marshall Smith

Author : Arthur James Marshall Smith

Arthur James Marshall Smith (aka) A.J.M. Smith was born on November 8, 1902, in Montreal, Quebec, Canada. He attended McGill University in Montreal, where he studied classics and philosophy. He was a prominent Canadian poet, anthologist, and critic. He was a leading figure in Canadian modernist poetry. Some of his notable poetry collections include:

· “The Book of Canadian Poetry” (1943)

· “News of the Phoenix” (1943)

· “The Classic Shade: Selected Poems” (1947)

Smith was an influential editor and anthologist. He edited several important anthologies of Canadian poetry, helping to shape the canon of Canadian literature. He played a significant role in promoting and advancing Canadian literature. His critical works and anthologies helped to establish a distinct Canadian literary identity.

Smith received several awards and honors for his contributions to literature, including the Governor General’s Award for Poetry in 1943.He continued to write and contribute to Canadian literature throughout his life. He also taught English literature at various universities.

A.J.M. Smith passed away on November 21, 1980, in Toronto, Ontario, Canada.He remains an important figure & his works continue to be studied and appreciated by scholars and readers alike.

William Butler Yeats

William Butler Yeats was born on June 13, 1865, in Sandymount, Dublin, Ireland. He spent much of his childhood in County Sligo, where his family owned a home. He came from a family with a strong literary background. His father, John Butler Yeats, was a well-known artist, and his brother, Jack Butler Yeats, became a renowned painter.

Yeats was educated in Dublin and later attended the Metropolitan School of Art in Dublin. He was largely educated at home by his parents and tutors due to health issues. He published numerous poetry collections throughout his career, including:

· “The Tower” (1928),

· “The Winding Stair and Other Poems” (1933),

· “Last Poems and Two Plays” (1939).

Yeats was deeply involved in the Irish nationalist movement. He was a member of the Irish Republican Brotherhood and served as a senator in the Irish Free State for a time. He was a co-founder of The Abbey Theatre in Dublin in 1904.The theatre played a crucial role in promoting Irish drama and literature.

Yeats was awarded the Nobel Prize in Literature in 1923. He was the first Irishman to receive this honor. He had a complex personal life, marked by unrequited love and tumultuous relationships. He passed away on January 28, 1939, in Menton, France. He was buried in Drumcliffe, County Sligo, Ireland, as per his wishes.

About the Poem:

Ode on the death of William Butler Yeats is a poem from the book “The Complete Poems (Part 1)” by A.J.M .Smith in 1941(2 years after W.B.Yeats’ death). It is written in memory of Yeats’. This poem talks about all the occurence that can be brought alive if Yeats was brought back. This poem is introduced as a Ode with 5 stanzas with 5 lines each. The poetic lines brings out it’s elegiac element.

This poem portrays the resilience and beauty found in nature amidst harsh conditions. It begins with imagery of a barren landscape, where an old tree blooms unexpectedly, symbolizing renewal and vitality. The focus then shifts to a wild swan, embodying primal energy and exuberance as it defies geographical boundaries and confronts the elements with grace. Throughout the poem, motifs of transformation and endurance are woven together, culminating in a celebration of the enduring power of nature’s beauty and resilience. Metaphorically speaking about the state of Irish.

Theme:

The poem explores themes of transformation, resilience, and the eternal nature of life. It contemplates the interplay between life and death, using natural elements and the swan’s journey as metaphors for the broader human experience. The contrast between harsh environments and unexpected beauty, as well as the celebration of life’s enduring glory, contributes to a theme of finding beauty and significance in the face of mortality.

Stanza wise Explanation:

Stanza 1: Natural Resilience

An old thorn tree in a stony place

Where the mountain stream has run dry,

Torn in the black wind under the race

Of the icicle-sharp kaleidoscopic white sky,

Bursts into sudden flower.

The first stanza talks about the situation of the Irish People & Country before W.B.Yeats. It describes the state of the country. The Irish Mountains had run dry and become a stony dry place with very old thorn trees. These elements represents that this place has been in this pitiful situation for a very long time. Symbolizing endurance and resilience of Irish people on a desolate landscape, possibly mirroring the loss or absence of life. Black wind and icicle-sharp kaleidoscopic white sky evokes a harsh, wintry setting with strong winds and a vivid, ever-changing sky. Surprising transformation or beauty emerging from a seemingly barren tree,Bursting of flower represents the potential of renewal, i.e., Birth of W.B.Yeats.

Stanza 2: Primal Energy

Under the central dome of winter and night

A wild swan spreads his fanatic wing.

Ancestralled energy of blood and power

Beats in his sinewy breast. And now the ravening

Soul, fulfilled, his first-last hour

Upon him, chooses to exult.

In the second stanza Smith introduces Yeats as a swan, a symbol of beauty and grace, amidst the harshness of winter, hinting at the contrast between life and death.He connects the swan to ancestral vigor, emphasizing life force and strength of the Irish.The ravening soul’s fulfilleds first-last hour denotes the swan’s impending death, but with a sense of fulfillment and celebration.Even though Yeats has met his end , he had no regrets as he believed that he fullfilled the purpose of his life.

Stanza 3: Transcendence

Over the edge of shivering Europe,

Over the chalk front of Kent, over Eire,

Dwarfing the crawling waves’ amoral savagery,

Daring the hiding clouds’ rhetorical tumult,

The white swan plummets the mountain top.

The third stanza,The swan is depicted as flying over the continent of Europe, which is described as “shivering,” implying a sense of coldness and vulnerability. This sets the tone for the swan’s daring flight into the unknown.’Dwarfing the crawling waves’ represents the contrast between the swan’s flight and the waves below.This imagery suggests the swan’s majestic presence and dominance over the chaotic and indifferent forces of nature. The swan fearlessly confronts the tumultuous clouds, indicating a sense of mystery portrayed as a bold and defiant act in the face of uncertainty and adversity. Despite the challenges and dangers it encounters, the swan continues its flight, symbolizing its Consistency, Possibly symbolizing a glorious end.

Stanza 4: Renewal and Transformation

The stream has suddenly pushed the papery leaves!

It digs a rustling channel of clear water

On the scarred flank of Ben Bulben.

The twisted tree is incandescent with flowers.

The swan leaps singing into the cold air:

This is a glory not for an hour.

The fourth stanza suggests a renewal or change in the landscape, possibly linked to the swan’s influence. It describes a rejuvenating effect on the land, with clear water flowing from the stream.This sudden surge of water symbolizes a renewal of life and vitality in the environment.The twisted tree reinforces the theme of unexpected beauty emerging from a harsh environment.The swan, with its characteristic grace and vigor, leaps into the cold air while singing. This action emphasizes the theme of vitality and the enduring beauty of nature. The beauty and vitality brought forth by the stream’s surge, symbolized by the blooming tree and the singing swan, are portrayed as lasting and profound, transcending the fleeting passage of time. The author states that Yeats has renewed the irish people from their desolate land.

Stanza 5: Eternal Beauty

Over the Galway shore

The white bird is flying

Forever, and crying

To the tumultuous throng

Of the sky his cold and passionate song.

The last stanza concludes with the image of the swan flying eternally, expressing its emotional song to the vast sky, symbolizing the enduring legacy of Yeats and the beauty of life even in the face of death.The swan’s flight, over the Galway shore in Ireland adds depth and context, grounding the poem in a tangible setting.The swan flying forever suggests a timeless quality to its journey, symbolizing the eternal nature of beauty and grace in the natural world.Description of the swan crying its cold and passionate song to the tumultuous throng of the ever-changing sky evokes a sense of both melancholy and fervor.

Literary Devices:

· Imagery: — The poem employs a vivid imagery to paint a picture of the desolate landscape, the swan’s flight, and the rejuvenation of nature .

· Symbolism:- The old thorn tree, the swan, and the various landscapes symbolize different aspects of life, death, and the enduring spirit.

· Personification:- The swan’s “fanatic wing” and the “ravening Soul” add human-like qualities to natural elements, enhancing the emotional depth of the poem.

· Contrast:- The contrast between the harsh, wintry landscape and the sudden burst of flowers, as well as the contrast between life and death, is a central device in the poem.

· Alliteration:- Phrases like “icicle-sharp kaleidoscopic” and “crawling waves’ amoral savagery” use alliteration to create rhythm and enhance the musicality of the language.

· Metaphor:- The swan’s flight serves as a metaphor for the journey of life, with its culmination in death portrayed as a moment of exultation and fulfillment.
